Timeline

It’s almost impossible to turn on a television these days and not find a reality television program of some sort. Ever since the great Writer’s Strike of 2007, so-called “unscripted” television has taken over, and it isn’t showing any sign of stopping. One of the many popular genres in the field is the singing competition show. These are programs made to challenge people’s skills at singing by diving into numerous styles and genres of music with the winner often taking home a ton of cash, recognition in the industry, and sometimes, a record contract.

Competition shows have been around forever with talent searching platforms like Star Search often focusing on music. While that show is certainly legendary, it wasn’t 100% about the music, which is why this list is focused on only those competitive shows that center entirely on singing. Shows like American Idol and The Voice are obvious contenders, but there are other more amazing series out there you may not have seen!

There truly are tons of examples of this genre, many from the UK, but not all singing competition shows are as good as the tracks they produce. There’s so much to choose from, but there are a few series that are considerably better than others thanks to the intense competition found in each episode. This list highlights the very best reality TV shows in the singing competition genre so don't forget to vote up your favorites. Then, check out shows about music that aren't competition shows - some of which feature faces you'll recognize from singing competitions.

Choi Jae-Bong

speed skater

June 19, 1980

He represented his country at the 1998 Winter Olympics in Nagano. At that time he was the holder of the junior World record at 1500 m, set in early December 1997 in Thialf, Heerenveen, where he clocked 1:52.25 to break the record. In November 1998 he broke the junior world record over 500 m into a new time of 36.30 in Calgary and a day later he broke his own 1500 m record again, this time 1:49.71 was his new best time. Due to these records and some other decent results in that same weekend he also broke the junior world record for the small allround classification to 153.689 points. He set 1:10.87 at the 1000 m in February 1999 and a total of 143.965 points for the sprint classification again in Calgary. As a senior, during his second Olympic Games, the 2002 Winter Olympics in Salt Lake City he finished 17th at the 500 m, 12th at the 1000 m and 21st at the 1500 m. He also represented South of Korea four years later during the 2006 Winter Olympics in Turin. In Italy he finished in his all-time best Olympic result, by becoming 8th at the 500 m. He also became 17th at the 1000 m. 500 m – 35.12, 12 February 2002, Salt Lake City 1000 m – 1:08.81, 16 February 2002, Salt Lake City 1500 m – 1:47.26, 19 February 2002, Salt Lake City 3000 m – 3:55.29, 15 November 1997, Calgary 5000 m – 6:49.61, 7 December 1997, Heerenveen 10000 m – 15:11.81, 23 February 1996, Seoul.

“Lawless Lawyer” has thrilled viewers with exciting action scenes and unpredictable plot twists in its story of two lawyers fighting the ultimate evil with their fists and wits. With only four episodes left to go, here are three things to look for in the last couple episodes of “Lawless Lawyer.”

Spoiler

Recently, Bong Sang Pil (played by Lee Joon Gi) found out that the person who had given him the mysterious notebook was in fact Cha Moon Sook (played by Lee Hye Young). Meanwhile, it was revealed that Ahn Oh Joo (played by Choi Min Soo) had been the one who ordered Choi Dae Woong’s (played by Ahn Nae Sang) murder. Ha Jae Yi’s (played by Seo Ye Ji) mother No Hyun Joo (played by Baek Joo Hee) used her newly exposed existence to plan for the future and created hope. After Cha Moon Sook’s big plan was revealed, Bong Sang Pil became even more determined, hinting at his big counterattack in the future.

1. Bong Sang Pil vs. Cha Moon Sook, who will be the final winner of their war?

Ever since the beginning of the drama, Bong Sang Pil vowed to chase after evil and now, he appears to be planning on making his revenge even more fervent. With Cha Moon Sook’s big picture revealed, Bong Sang Pil’s response will be unpredictable. He has also not stopped his pursuit after revealing that Cha Moon Sook and Ahn Oh Joo were the true murderers behind his mother’s death. Rather, he has strengthened his vow to chase after evil and has shown that he is currently planning a counterattack.

A source from the production staff stated, “Cha Moon Sook’s revealed greater plan and their determination to topple each other over will add even more energy to the drama.”

2. The seven’s committee relationships becoming twisted amongst conspiracy and betrayal

The relationship between the seven-person committee has become quite complicated due to Cha Moon Sook’s change of heart. New relationships have developed while their commitment on the front regarding Bong Sang Pil and Ha Jae Yi has strengthened. However, since Cha Moon Sook was a key, explosive player in the committee, it is unknown how the other members will respond.

3. No Hyun Joo’s fate after revealing herself to Cha Moon Sook

Throughout the drama, No Hyun Joo was merely Cha Moon Sook’s chiropractor and spy into the law firm. However, when she decided she could no longer put her daughter Ha Jae Yi in danger, she persuaded Bong Sang Pil to break up with her. She even purposefully exposed herself to Cha Moon Sook and was kidnapped by his bodyguards. To top it off, Ha Jae Yi believes that Bong Sang Pil used her for her quest for revenge over her mother. However, their 18-year partnership has proven that they have become even stronger under adversary. It remains to be seen whether No Hyun Joo will be able to convince Cha Moon Sook of her identity and how Bong Sang Pil and Ha Jae Yi will work together to overcome further obstacles.

A source from the production staff stated, “If the beginning of the drama focused on the law firm’s promise to pursue evil, then the end of the drama will show a new atmosphere and transformation. All of the characters’ cards have been played, and Bong Sang Pil and Ha Jae Yi have become even closer.”

“Lawless Lawyer” airs every Saturday and Sunday at 9 p.m. KST.

Sharon Choi, Bong Joon-ho's translator, receives major award

Bong Joon-ho's translator, who became an instant global sensation when the director of "Parasite" won the Academy Award earlier this year, received the YoungSan Diplomat Award on Wednesday for her role in enhancing Korea's international image.Choi Sung-jae, better known as Sharon Choi, is not a professional translator, but she charmed audiences with her precise yet witty interpretations that managed to convey the ideas and capture the character of the enigmatic Bong.Clips of Choi's online interview with Canadian-American actor Sandra Oh on the subject of BBC drama series "Killing Eve" became a viral hit recently for her insightful questions not only about the story but also social issues. The interview, supposed to go for 15 minutes, was extended to 40 minutes.The YoungSan Diplomat Award is annually presented by the Seoul Forum for International Affairs to recognize a public official and a civilian for their contributions to Korea's image and the country's diplomatic interests.According to Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Choi and Kang Hyung-sik, the head of foreign ministry's international safety management bureau, are the winners of the 12th YoungSan Diplomat Award. Kang, also known as the "Invisible hand" for managing the country's responses to global incidents and recently to the coronavirus pandemic, was recognized for having contributed greatly to the repatriation of Korean citizens stuck abroad.Foreign Minister Kang Kyung-hwa will attend the ceremony and congratulate the recipients.BY LEE JAE-LIM [lee.jaelim@joongang.co.kr]

Choi Jae-bong (Korean: 최재봉, Hanja: 崔財鳳, born 19 June 1980) is a South Korean speed skater. He represented his country at the 1998 Winter Olympics in Nagano. At that time he was the holder of the junior World record at 1500 m, set in early December 1997 in Thialf, Heerenveen, where he clocked 1:52.25 to break the record. In Nagano where he finished in 12th position he broke his own world junior record to a new best time of 1:51.47, which was 0.78 of a second faster. He also finished in 29th position at the 5000 m. In November 1998 he broke the junior world record over 500 m into a new time of 36.30 in Calgary and a day later he broke his own 1500 m record again, this time 1:49.71 was his new best time. Due to these records and some other decent results in that same weekend he also broke the junior world record for the small allround classification to 153.689 points. That same season he won the bronze medal at the World Junior Allround Championships and broke another two world records. He set 1:10.87 at the 1000 m in February 1999 and a total of 143.965 points for the sprint classification again in Calgary.

South Korean speed skater

Quick facts: Personal information, Born, Height, Weight, S... ▼

As a senior, during his second Olympic Games, the 2002 Winter Olympics in Salt Lake City he finished 17th at the 500 m, 12th at the 1000 m and 21st at the 1500 m. He also represented South Korea four years later during the 2006 Winter Olympics in Turin. In Italy he finished in his all-time best Olympic result, by becoming 8th at the 500 m. He also became 17th at the 1000 m.
